metadata.title: Tab views | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page describing tab views, a UI component that presents multiple mutually exclusive panes of content in the same area, which people can switch between using a tabbed control. The document covers best practices, anatomy, platform considerations, and related resources.

content.text: Tab views
A tab view presents multiple mutually exclusive panes of content in the same area, which people can switch between using a tabbed control.

content.description: A stylized illustration of a tab view component showing two tabs labeled 'Label' and 'Label'. The illustration uses a warm coral/salmon red color palette (#FF6B6B or similar) against a white background. The first tab appears selected (solid background) while the second tab is unselected (outlined). The illustration shows a rounded rectangle container with the tabbed control at the top. Visual styling includes soft shadows and rounded corners consistent with Apple's modern design language. The overall appearance demonstrates the concept of mutually exclusive content panes with tab-based navigation.
content.composition: Centered illustration with tab control at top, content area below. The tabs are positioned horizontally at the top edge of a rounded rectangle container.
content.technicalDetails: Vector illustration demonstrating tab view anatomy
content.contextualRelevance: Hero illustration introducing the tab views component, showing the basic visual structure and tab labeling concept

content.text: Best practices

Use a tab view to present closely related areas of content. The appearance of a tab view provides a strong visual indication of enclosure. People expect each tab to display content that is in some way similar or related to the content in the other tabs.
content.leadingSentence: Use a tab view to present closely related areas of content.

content.text: Make sure the controls within a pane affect content only in the same pane. Panes are mutually exclusive, so ensure they're fully self-contained.
content.leadingSentence: Make sure the controls within a pane affect content only in the same pane.

content.text: Provide a label for each tab that describes the contents of its pane. A good label helps people predict the contents of a pane before clicking or tapping its tab. In general, use nouns or short noun phrases for tab labels. A verb or short verb phrase may make sense in some contexts. Use title-style capitalization for tab labels.
content.leadingSentence: Provide a label for each tab that describes the contents of its pane.

content.text: Avoid using a pop-up button to switch between tabs. A tabbed control is efficient because it requires a single click or tap to make a selection, whereas a pop-up button requires two. A tabbed control also presents all choices onscreen at the same time, whereas people must click a pop-up button to see its choices. Note that a pop-up button can be a reasonable alternative in cases where there are too many panes of content to reasonably display with tabs.
content.leadingSentence: Avoid using a pop-up button to switch between tabs.

content.text: Avoid providing more than six tabs in a tab view. Having more than six tabs can be overwhelming and create layout issues. If you need to present six or more tabs, consider another way to implement the interface. For example, you could instead present each tab as a view option in a pop-up button menu.
content.leadingSentence: Avoid providing more than six tabs in a tab view.

content.text: For developer guidance, see NSTabView.
Anatomy
The tabbed control appears on the top edge of the content area. You can choose to hide the control, which is appropriate for an app that switches between panes programmatically.

content.description: A macOS window screenshot showing a tab view component. The window has the standard macOS window controls (red, yellow, green circles) in the top-left corner. Below the window controls is a segmented tab bar with three tabs labeled 'First', 'Second', and 'Third'. The 'First' tab appears selected. The tab control sits at the top edge of the content area within a standard macOS window frame with light gray background.
content.composition: Standard macOS window layout with tab control positioned at top of content area, below window title bar
content.technicalDetails: macOS window screenshot showing tab view anatomy with three tabs in a standard window frame
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates the anatomy of a tab view showing the tabbed control position at the top edge of the content area

content.text: When you hide the tabbed control, the content area can be borderless, bezeled, or bordered with a line. A borderless view can be solid or transparent.

In general, inset a tab view by leaving a margin of window-body area on all sides of a tab view. This layout looks clean and leaves room for additional controls that aren't directly related to the contents of the tab view. You can extend a tab view to meet the window edges, but this layout is unusual.
content.leadingSentence: In general, inset a tab view by leaving a margin of window-body area on all sides of a tab view.

content.text: Platform considerations
Not supported in iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, or visionOS.
iOS, iPadOS
For similar functionality, consider using a segmented control instead.
watchOS
watchOS displays tab views using page controls. For developer guidance, see TabView and verticalPage.

content.description: A stylized illustration of an Apple Watch showing the watchOS tab view implementation. The illustration shows a simplified Apple Watch outline (rectangular with rounded corners) in dark gray/black. Inside the watch face is a representation of the page control interface with a vertical page indicator (small dots) on the right side of the display, indicating multiple pages/tabs that can be swiped between. The watch face area is shown in a lighter shade suggesting content area.
content.composition: Centered Apple Watch device outline with page control indicator visible on the right edge of the display
content.technicalDetails: watchOS implementation showing vertical page-based tab navigation
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates how tab views are implemented on watchOS using page controls with vertical swiping

pages.pageSummary: Apple Developer Documentation page for Tab views - a UI component that presents multiple mutually exclusive content panes with a tabbed control for switching between them. The page covers best practices (use for related content, self-contained panes, descriptive labels, avoid pop-ups, max 6 tabs), anatomy (tabbed control position, border options, margin recommendations), and platform considerations (not supported on iOS/iPadOS/tvOS/visionOS - use segmented controls instead; watchOS uses page controls). Includes links to related documentation for TabView (SwiftUI) and NSTabView (AppKit).

crossPageElements.runningFooters: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

sections.title: Tab views
sections.summary: Introduction defining tab views as UI components for presenting mutually exclusive content panes with tabbed switching control

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Five key guidelines: use for related content, keep panes self-contained, use descriptive noun labels with title capitalization, avoid pop-up buttons for tab switching, limit to maximum six tabs

sections.title: Anatomy
sections.summary: Technical description of tab view structure: tabbed control at top edge, optional hiding, border styles (borderless/bezeled/bordered), and margin/inset recommendations

subsections.summary: Tab views not supported - use segmented controls instead

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document follows Apple's standard HIG documentation structure: begins with component definition and hero illustration, proceeds through best practices guidelines, explains anatomical structure with visual examples, covers platform-specific considerations for iOS/iPadOS and watchOS, provides resource links to related documentation and developer APIs, and concludes with a change log tracking documentation updates.

keyTerms.definition: A UI component that presents multiple mutually exclusive panes of content in the same area, which people can switch between using a tabbed control
The interactive element at the top of a tab view that allows users to switch between panes with a single click or tap
A self-contained content area within a tab view that is mutually exclusive with other panes
AppKit class for implementing tab views in macOS applications
SwiftUI view for implementing tab-based navigation across Apple platforms
watchOS implementation of tab views using vertical page-based navigation
Recommended alternative to tab views on iOS and iPadOS
SwiftUI TabViewStyle for watchOS vertical page navigation

keyFindings: Tab views are primarily a macOS component - not supported on iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, or visionOS
Maximum recommended tabs is six to avoid overwhelming users and layout issues
Tab labels should use nouns or short noun phrases with title-style capitalization
Tabbed controls are more efficient than pop-up buttons (single click vs. two clicks)
watchOS implements tab views differently using page controls with vertical swiping
Panes within a tab view must be fully self-contained and mutually exclusive
Tab views should generally be inset with margins rather than extending to window edges
The tabbed control can be hidden for programmatic pane switching

designConstraints.labelContent: nouns or short noun phrases preferred
designConstraints.layoutRecommendation: inset with window-body margins on all sides

designDecisions.rationale: Helps people predict pane contents before clicking/tapping

designDecisions.decision: Single-click tab switching over pop-up buttons
designDecisions.rationale: More efficient interaction (1 click vs 2) and shows all options simultaneously
Prevents overwhelming users and avoids layout issues
Maintains mutual exclusivity and clear content separation
Creates clean layout and leaves room for additional controls

designDecisions.decision: Use segmented controls on iOS/iPadOS instead
designDecisions.rationale: Tab views are not natively supported on mobile platforms
Better suited for small screen and touch/swipe interaction model
